summary: In this 1940 West Africa Court of Appeal decision, James Anuku appealed his conviction for murder, arguing that the trial judge erred in rejecting the defense of insanity. The trial judge acknowledged that Anuku was not mentally normal but held that the evidence was insufficiently explicit to establish legal insanity under section 28 of the Criminal Code. The appellate court upheld the conviction, citing R. v. True, 16 C.A.R. 167, and affirmed that the judge, as the trier of fact, was entitled to conclude that the totality of the evidence did not prove insanity at the time of the offense. The appeal was dismissed.
legalKeywords: mental state at time of offense
verdict: Appeal dismissed; conviction for murder upheld.
citations: R. v. True, 16 Criminal Appeal Report, p.167

The appellate court upheld the trial judge's evaluation, emphasizing that the facts as a whole did not establish insanity at the time of the act.

No medical evidence was presented by the prosecution, but the judge was still entitled to reject the defense based on the totality of the evidence.
The appeal was dismissed because the court found no misdirection in law or error in factual assessment.
